message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest pulmonary embolism, and since she is pregnant, a ventilation-perfusion scan is the recommended next step in diagnosis. CT angiogram and ultrasound are also used to diagnose pulmonary embolism, but ventilation-perfusion scan has less radiation exposure. D-dimer is not very specific and can be elevated in other conditions as well.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a possible pulmonary embolism, and the safest imaging test for pregnant patients is ventilation-perfusion scan. CT angiogram and D-dimer expose the fetus to radiation, while ultrasound is not a preferred imaging modality for diagnosing pulmonary embolism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a possible pulmonary embolism (PE). Among the options, ventilation-perfusion scan (V/Q scan) is the most appropriate initial diagnostic test for PE in a pregnant patient with suspected PE as it has a low radiation dose and safety profile. CT angiogram is a second-line test if the V/Q scan is inconclusive or contraindicated. D-dimer tests are nonspecific and cannot be relied upon in pregnant patients. Ultrasound is not useful in the diagnosis of PE.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and history suggest a high likelihood of pulmonary embolism. While CT angiogram, D-dimer, and ultrasound can all be useful diagnostic tools, ventilation-perfusion scan is considered the next best step in diagnosis to evaluate for pulmonary embolism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a possible pulmonary embolism, and a ventilation-perfusion scan would be more appropriate in this situation than a CT angiogram or ultrasound. A D-dimer test is used to rule out a pulmonary embolism but is not the next best step in diagnosis in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of negative pregnancy tests and a smoking history, making pulmonary embolism likely. A ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) scan is the best initial test for pulmonary embolism, as it can assess lung function and assess for abnormalities in blood flow. CT angiogram is an option but comes with greater radiation exposure. D-dimer is less specific than V/Q scan, and ultrasound is not appropriate in the context of suspected pulmonary embolism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest possible pulmonary embolism, which can be confirmed or ruled out using ventilation-perfusion scan. CT angiogram and ultrasound can also be used, but ventilation-perfusion scan is the initial test of choice. D-dimer may be elevated in pregnancy and smoking, making it less specific.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of negative pregnancy tests and a large abdominal pannus, which could indicate a false-positive pregnancy test due to a heterophile antibody. Therefore, a ventilation-perfusion scan would be the best next step to determine if there is indeed a pulmonary embolism causing her symptoms. CT angiogram and ultrasound can also be helpful in the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism, but ventilation-perfusion scan is the preferred first test in this scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of mental illness and a smoking history, making it more likely for her to have a pulmonary embolism (PE). The symptoms of chest pain and difficulty breathing, along with the positive pregnancy test, increase suspicion for PE. The next best step in diagnosis would be a ventilation-perfusion scan (V/Q scan), which is a non-invasive test that can show if there is a blockage in the lungs. CT angiogram and ultrasound are also possible tests for diagnosing PE, but they are more invasive and have more risks associated with them. D-dimer is a blood test that can be used to screen for PE, but it is less specific and can give false positive results in pregnant women.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and pregnancy test suggest the possibility of pulmonary embolism, and ventilation-perfusion scan is the most appropriate test to diagnose or rule out pulmonary embolism. CT angiogram is also a good option but not recommended in pregnant patients. D-dimer is not specific enough and ultrasound is not useful for pulmonary embolism diagnosis.
